StoreShop PageDonationsMy Account Shop Page Donations My Account Shop Page Donations My Account ContactContact UsSpeaking Requests Contact Us Speaking Requests Contact Us Speaking Requests Subscribe to Newsletter **An Argument in favor of Justification by Faith alone in Christ alone** byMatt Slick|May 15, 2025|Doctrine and Theology,Christian Theology A lot of people in the Roman Catholic and the Eastern Orthodox Churches deny the biblical doctrine of justification by faith alone in Christ alone. Generally speaking, they say that it must be a faith that has works. In light of this, many quote James 2:24 in order to argue against Romans 3:28, 4:5, Galatians 2:16, etc. They set scripture against scripture and fail to analyze contexts. Therefore, this article is a defense of justification by faith alone.I hope it helps you stand firm in the truth of God’s word. Justification before God is either by faith alone or it is not by faith alone.By ‘faith’ alone is meant the belief/trust that is granted by God (Phil. 1:29) that is in Jesus (John 6:29). Because this faith is granted by God and is in Jesus, the faith is real and genuine. It is not mere mental assent. It accompanies regeneration.Phil. 1:29, “For to you it has been granted for Christ’s sake, not only to believe in Him, but also to suffer for His sake.”John 6:29, “Jesus answered and said to them, ‘This is the work of God, that you believe in Him whom He has sent.'”By ‘justification’ is meant the crediting of righteousness that is received by faith (Rom. 4:5) apart from the works of the Law (Rom. 3:28; Gal. 2:16; Phil. 3:9).Rom. 4:5, “But to the one who does not work, but believes in Him who justifies the ungodly, his faith is credited as righteousness.”Rom. 3:28, “For we maintain that a man is justified by faith apart from works of the Law.”Gal. 2:16, “nevertheless knowing that a man is not justified by the works of the Law but through faith in Christ Jesus, even we have believed in Christ Jesus, so that we may be justified by faith in Christ and not by the works of the Law; since by the works of the Law no flesh will be justified.”Phil. 3:9, “and may be found in Him, not having a righteousness of my own derived from the Law, but that which is through faith in Christ, the righteousness which comes from God on the basis of faith,”Note: Roman Catholics and Eastern Orthodox often claim that the “Law” in Romans 3:28, 4:5, and Galatians 2:16 refers to the ceremonial law. However, this interpretation is flawed for several reasons.First, Romans 3:20 states that “through the Law comes the knowledge of sin.” The ceremonial law does not define sin (Rom. 5:20; 1 John 3:4); it responds to it. Romans 7:7 reinforces this by citing the command “You shall not covet,” which comes from the Ten Commandments (Exodus 20:17). This is moral law, not ceremonial law.Second, Rom. 3:19 says the Law makes “all the world accountable to God.” The ceremonial law was given only to Israel and cannot universally condemn the world. Only the moral law can apply to all humanity.Third, in Rom’. 4:1-5, Paul presents Abraham as the exemplar of justification by faith, and Abraham lived before the ceremonial law was instituted through Moses.Finally, Rom. 5:13-14 says, “sin is not imputed when there is no law,” yet “death reigned from Adam to Moses.” This implies that people were still judged for sin before the ceremonial law existed; therefore, another kind of law must have been in effect besides the ceremonial law, namely the moral law. Therefore, the broader context shows that Paul’s references to “the Law” in these chapters cannot be restricted to the ceremonial law, but must refer to the moral law which condemns all humanity.Short:All the world is accountable to God not by the ceremonial law, but by the moral law (Rom. 3:19). It is through the moral law that we have the knowledge of sin (Rom. 3:20). Therefore it cannot be the ceremonial law that brings wrath (Rom. 4:15) since not all people had the ceremonial law. Death reigned from Adam to Moses before the ceremonial law was given, so the moral law must have been in effect (Rom. 5:13-14). Paul refers to the moral law (Rom. 7:7). So, Romans 3:28; 4:5; Gal. 2:16; Phil. 3:9, etc., cannot be about the ceremonial law.Exodus 20:17, “You shall not covet your neighbor’s house; you shall not covet your neighbor’s wife or his male servant or his female servant or his ox or his donkey or anything that belongs to your neighbor.”Rom. 3:19, “Now we know that whatever the Law says, it speaks to those who are under the Law, so that every mouth may be closed and all the world may become accountable to God.”Rom. 3:20, “because by the works of the Law no flesh will be justified in His sight; for through the Law comes the knowledge of sin.”Rom. 3:28, “For we maintain that a man is justified by faith apart from works of the Law.”Rom. 4:1–5, “What then shall we say that Abraham, our forefather according to the flesh, has found? 2 For if Abraham was justified by works, he has something to boast about, but not before God. 3 For what does the Scripture say? “Abraham believed God, and it was credited to him as righteousness.” 4 Now to the one who works, his wage is not credited as a favor, but as what is due. 5 But to the one who does not work, but believes in Him who justifies the ungodly, his faith is credited as righteousness.”Rom. 4:15, “for the Law brings about wrath, but where there is no law, there also is no violation.”Rom. 5:13–14, “for until the Law sin was in the world, but sin is not imputed when there is no law. 14 Nevertheless, death reigned from Adam until Moses, even over those who had not sinned in the likeness of the offense of Adam, who is a type of Him who was to come.”Rom. 5:20, “The Law came in so that the transgression would increase; but where sin increased, grace abounded all the more,”Rom. 7:7, “What shall we say then? Is the Law sin? May it never be! On the contrary, I would not have come to know sin except through the Law; for I would not have known about coveting if the Law had not said, “You shall not covet.”Gal. 2:16, “nevertheless knowing that a man is not justified by the works of the Law but through faith in Christ Jesus, even we have believed in Christ Jesus, so that we may be justified by faith in Christ and not by the works of the Law; since by the works of the Law no flesh will be justified.”Phil. 3:9, “and may be found in Him, not having a righteousness of my own derived from the Law, but that which is through faith in Christ, the righteousness which comes from God on the basis of faith,”1 John 3:4, “Everyone who practices sin also practices lawlessness; and sin is lawlessness.” By ‘faith’ alone is meant the belief/trust that is granted by God (Phil. 1:29) that is in Jesus (John 6:29). This is a true dichotomy.A true dichotomy is when there are only two possibilities. So, our justification is by the faith that God grants us alone or is not the case that is by the faith that God grants us alone.James 2:24, “You see that a man is justified by works and not by faith alone.”The context of James 2:24 begins in verse 14, where James talks about a faith that has no works, and he says, “Can that faith save him?” What faith? The faith that is dead (ascentia – mental acknowledgment), v. 17. Furthermore, James is talking about works presented to people, not before God, because in verse 18 he says, “Show me your faith without the works, and I will show you my faith by my works.” This is dealing with the horizontal, that is, between people. This is talking about justification before people, not before God. James declares that even the demons have faith (v. 19). He again is mentioning false faith; that is, faith that has no true manifestation of good works. V. 21 is where Paul says Abraham was justified by works. Now, no Roman Catholic would say that works justify before God. Paul, of course, contradicts that as well (Rom. 3:28; 4:5, etc.) Again, since this is about justification before people, not before God (v. 18) as is consistent with other Scriptures (Rom. 3:28; 4:1-5; Gal. 2:16, 21), we can then understand that the works that James is talking about are not works that save you or contribute to salvation, but works that are the manifestation of true faith (fiducia – heartfelt faith and trust). Furthermore, when it says that “a man it is justified by works and not by faith alone, the context is justification before people (v. 18), not before God (Rom. 4:1-5). In other words, “show me your faith without the works, and I will show you my faith by my works” (James 2:18). So, James is consistent with the rest of Scripture. All you need to do is look at the context.In light of this, many people appeal to James 2:24 to state that justification before God is by works, and not faith alone.Furthermore, if they use James 2:24 as a statement in support of their position that works and faith save, then,from their perspective, they must be consistent and say that their justification before God is by works, as the text says, and not by faith alone. So then, do they agree that they are justified before God by their works of faith and good works? They would have to say that works justify us before God, along with our faith. But that, of course, contradicts what is clearly taught above in point 1.
